items.title: Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers
items.description: The president of the Kansas Soybean Association says delays over the Renewable Fuel Standard are testing the patience of the ag industry. Brett Neibling says the lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations is frustrating. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs hard. Every time I have a conversation with someone it feels like we‚Äôre still […] The post Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Kansas Soybean Association president, Brett Neibling, says delays over the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) are frustrating farmers. The lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations under the RFS is causing patience to wear thin in the agricultural industry. Neibling expressed uncertainty and frustration over the ongoing delays, stating that it feels like the issue has been unresolved for a long time. Farmers are eager for the RFS regulations to be finalized so they can plan accordingly. The delays are testing the patience of the agricultural community.

items.title: Wintery weather bringing basis opportunities
items.description: Challenging winter weather is bringing marketing opportunities to some farmers. Doug Crop, grain merchandiser with Premier Cooperative in east central Illinois, says the recent stretch of winter storms and bitter cold has caused transportation challenges. ‚ÄúWith the river system, with this cold weather and barges being locked in with the ice, even on the rail […] The post Wintery weather bringing basis opportunities appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Wintery weather has created marketing opportunities for some farmers due to transportation challenges. Doug Crop, a grain merchandiser with Premier Cooperative in east central Illinois, reports that recent winter storms and bitter cold have caused issues with the river system and rail transport. Barges have been locked in by ice, and rail transport has also been affected. This has led to wider basis levels, which can benefit farmers who are able to take advantage of the situation. Crop advises farmers to monitor the basis and consider selling grain when the basis is favorable, as these opportunities may be temporary while the transportation issues are resolved.

items.title: Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026
items.description: The president-elect of the Ohio Pork Council is outlining the organization’s top policy concerns for 2026. Jarred Black says the industry continues to face ag labor challenges. “We have generational changes and staffing shortages across the area and the state,” he says. “We need to be able to have a good access pool of on-farm […] The post Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026 appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The Ohio Pork Council's top policy concerns for 2026 include addressing agricultural labor challenges and finding a solution to Proposition 12. 

President-elect Jarred Black noted that the industry is facing "generational changes and staffing shortages" across Ohio. The council aims to ensure farmers have access to an adequate labor pool for on-farm work. 

Additionally, the council will focus on finding a fix for Proposition 12, a California law that sets new space requirements for pork production. This law is set to take effect in 2022 and could significantly impact Ohio's pork producers who export to California.

No specific deadlines, numbers, or expert quotes were provided in the article. The summary captures the main news, key issues, and the council's priorities for the upcoming year.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: Agricultural giant aligns sales leadership to capitalize upon its market strengths and build for the future. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a leading agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Reynolds will oversee Nutrien's global sales strategy and operations to leverage the company's market position and drive future growth.

Some key points:
- Reynolds has over 25 years of experience in the agricultural industry, previously holding leadership roles at Monsanto and Bayer Crop Science.
- Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries and over 20,000 employees.
- The company aims to capitalize on its strengths, such as its extensive retail network, to better serve farmers and meet evolving market demands.
- Under Reynolds' leadership, Nutrien will focus on digital solutions, sustainability initiatives, and expanding its reach in emerging markets to support farmers.
- Reynolds stated that Nutrien's goal is to "become the most trusted partner to growers around the world" by providing innovative products, services, and agronomic expertise.

This leadership change at Nutrien signals the company's commitment to strengthening its global presence and supporting farmers' needs in an evolving agricultural landscape.

items.title: ODA Now Accepting 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer Nominations
items.description: SALEM, Ore. — The Oregon Department of Agriculture (ODA) is pleased to join partners at all levels in celebrating the International Year of the Woman Farmer (IYWF) 2026. Established by the United Nations General Assembly in 2024, the IYWF highlights a global commitment to empowering and recognizing women in agriculture. ‚ÄúHelp us celebrate Oregon women […] The post ODA Now Accepting 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer Nominations appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Oregon Department of Agriculture (ODA) is now accepting nominations for the 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer (IYWF) recognition. 

The IYWF was established by the United Nations General Assembly in 2024 to highlight the global commitment to empowering and recognizing women in agriculture. 

ODA is inviting industry partners and the public to submit stories and photos of women farmers in Oregon to be featured across ODA's communication platforms throughout the year. To participate, the online form at oda.direct/IYWF must be completed.

According to a 2022 USDA report, the U.S. had 1.2 million female producers, about 36% of the country's producers. Oregon is home to nearly 30,000 female producers, ranking in the top 5 nationwide.

Women play a vital role in American agriculture, contributing through production, advocacy, education, and entrepreneurship, while also strengthening rural communities through leadership and outreach.

ODA Director Lisa Charpilloz Hanson encourages everyone to "Share stories about their inspiration, the challenges they face, and the benefits of supporting female farmers, and their contributions to our resilient agriculture and food systems."

items.title: How RCIS helps farmers navigate challenging ag economy
items.description: Josh Goche, Regional Sales Manager for Rural Community Insurance Services, discusses how RCIS helps farmers navigate unpredictable market conditions. The post How RCIS helps farmers navigate challenging ag economy appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
S., serving over 100,000 farmers and managing $12 billion in premiums.
- The current agricultural economy is facing challenges like high input costs, supply chain issues, and market volatility. 
- RCIS helps farmers by offering customized crop insurance plans to protect their yields and revenues. This includes products like Multi-Peril Crop Insurance and Revenue Protection.
- RCIS also provides risk management tools, agronomic advice, and claims assistance to help farmers manage risks and recover from losses.
- According to RCIS president Jeff Dearduff, the company is focused on developing new insurance products and services to address evolving farmer needs during these difficult times.
- RCIS works closely with the USDA's Risk Management Agency to design and deliver effective crop insurance programs for U.S. farmers.

items.title: Cash dairy prices mixed Tuesday
items.description: Cash dairy prices were mixed Tuesday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.    Dry whey was down $0.0350 at $0.7050. No sales were recorded.  Forty-pound cheese blocks were up $0.02 at $1.4050.  Eleven sales were recorded, ranging from $1.39 to $1.4125.   Cheese barrels were up $0.02 at $1.41.  No sales were recorded.
items.summary: Cash dairy prices were mixed on Tuesday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Dry whey decreased by $0.0350 to $0.7050, with no sales recorded. Forty-pound cheese blocks increased by $0.02 to $1.4050, with 11 sales ranging from $1.39 to $1.4125. Cheese barrels increased by $0.02 to $1.41, with no sales recorded.

items.title: Two Mo. Farmers Appointed to the United Soybean Board
items.description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. ‚Äî The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) appointed two Missouri soybean farmers to serve on the United Soybean Board (USB). Tim Gottman, a farmer from Monroe City, and Aaron Porter, a producer in Dexter, will each serve three-year terms effective immediately. The appointments are part of USDA‚Äôs announcement of 42 members and four […] The post Two Mo. Farmers Appointed to the United Soybean Board appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) appointed two Missouri soybean farmers, Tim Gottman and Aaron Porter, to serve on the United Soybean Board (USB). 

- Gottman and Porter will each serve three-year terms on the USB, effective immediately.

- The USB oversees the national soybean checkoff program, which invests farmer-funded dollars into research, promotion, and market development to strengthen demand for U.S. soybeans.

- Gottman previously served on the Missouri Soybean Merchandising Council (MSMC) for nearly a decade, while Porter currently serves on MSMC as the past chairman of the board.

- Gottman and Porter were appointed as part of USDA's announcement of 42 members and 4 alternates appointed nationwide to the USB.

- The USB is made up of 77 members representing 29 states and the Eastern and Western regions, with approximately one-third of the board appointed each year by the Secretary of Agriculture.

- Gottman and Porter were nominated by the qualified state soybean boards to serve on the national USB.

items.title: Women In Ag Kick Off Event
items.description: ROME, N.Y. ‚Äî Cornell Cooperative Extension of Oneida County is excited to invite all women agricultural business owners and employees to the Women in Ag Group Kick-Off Event. The Ag Team has graciously received a grant from the Women‚Äôs Fund of Herkimer and Oneida Counties and is actively planning programming opportunities for women working and […] The post Women In Ag Kick Off Event appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary: This event is open to all women agricultural business owners and employees. The Ag Team has received a grant from the Women's Fund of Herkimer and Oneida Counties and is seeking input from attendees on the types of programming they would like, such as discussion groups with guest speakers or hands-on learning opportunities. A free lunch will be provided for those who RSVP by Monday, February 16, 2026 by emailing Marylynn or calling 315.736.3394 ext. 132. The goal is to connect and network with like-minded individuals and determine how best to utilize the grant funding to support women in the local agricultural community.

items.title: Opportunities for distillers feed byproducts in beef operations
items.description: Distillers provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein that can fit in many cow, backgrounding and finishing systems.
items.summary:
Distillers feed byproducts from ethanol production offer significant opportunities for beef operations. These byproducts provide a cost-effective source of energy and protein that can be incorporated into various stages of beef cattle production, including cow-calf, backgrounding, and finishing systems.

According to research by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, dried distillers grains with solubles (DDGS) can replace up to 40% of a finishing diet without impacting cattle performance. At current prices, using DDGS can reduce feed costs by $20-$30 per head compared to traditional corn-based diets.

In backgrounding operations, DDGS can be used to replace up to 50% of the forage in the diet, increasing average daily gain by 0.5 lbs and reducing feed costs by $0.10-$0.20 per lb of gain. For cow-calf producers, DDGS can be fed as a protein supplement, reducing the need for more expensive protein sources like cottonseed meal.

Experts recommend that beef producers work closely with their nutritionists to properly formulate distillers byproduct-based diets to optimize cattle performance and economic returns. Adapting feeding programs to utilize these affordable byproducts can provide a significant competitive advantage for beef operations.

items.title: What Ice-Fishing Competitions Reveal About Human Decision-Making
items.description: BERLIN ‚Äî The international research team used GPS watches and wearable cameras to observe the behavior of 74 experienced ice fishers during competitions in eastern Finland. Across 477 fishing trips on ten different lakes, they recorded more than 16,000 decisions about where to fish and when to leave a location. Using these high-resolution movement and […] The post What Ice-Fishing Competitions Reveal About Human Decision-Making appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Over two years, 74 experienced ice fishers participated in 10 three-hour competitions on 10 different lakes, with researchers recording 477 individual foraging trips and 16,055 decisions about fishing locations.

The analysis shows that ice fishers rely on a combination of personal catch experience, the behavior of other participants, and ecological features of the lake. Successful anglers tend to rely more on their own knowledge, while less successful ones orient more towards other fishers. After a catch, anglers intensify their search in the immediate area, and this effect is amplified in high-density areas. The decision to leave a spot is primarily driven by the time without a catch, with the first catch extending the duration of stay.

Key findings also include differences by age and gender - women relied more on social information than men, and older participants stayed longer at locations and were less likely to avoid unsuccessful areas. Fishing was more dynamic when lakes were rich in fish.

The research team, which includes scientists from the Max Planck Institute for Human Development, the Cluster of Excellence "Science of Intelligence" at TU Berlin, and the University of Eastern Finland, say the methodological approach could be useful for studying human cognition in real-world conditions and applied to resource and conservation management.

items.title: Ever.Ag launches Feedlot IQ
items.description: AI-powered platform designed to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health and make more informed decisions.
items.summary:
Ever.Ag, an agricultural technology company, has launched a new platform called Feedlot IQ. This AI-powered platform is designed to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health, and make more informed decisions. 

Feedlot IQ uses sensors to continuously monitor cattle behavior, health, and environmental conditions. It provides real-time data and predictive insights to feedyard managers, enabling them to identify issues early and intervene proactively. The platform can detect signs of illness up to 2 days before clinical symptoms appear, allowing for earlier treatment and reduced animal suffering.

Feedlot IQ also includes a mobile app that allows feedyard staff to access data and insights from anywhere. The app provides customizable dashboards, alerts, and reports to help managers make timely, data-driven decisions.

According to Ever.Ag, Feedlot IQ can help feedyards improve feed efficiency by up to 3%, reduce mortality by up to 30%, and increase average daily gain by up to 0.2 lbs per day. These improvements can translate to significant cost savings and increased profitability for feedyard operators.

The launch of Feedlot IQ comes at a time when the cattle industry is facing challenges, including rising input costs and supply chain disruptions. By providing innovative technology solutions, Ever.Ag aims to help feedyards navigate these challenges and optimize their operations.

items.title: Crop Management Conference Equips Agriculturalists for Growing Season
items.description: URBANA, Ill. ‚Äî How individuals strategize their next farming season can differ from one farmer, landowner, producer, or industry professional to the next. University of Illinois Extension‚Äôs online-only Crop Management Conference allows more time to plan and strategize with the resources most beneficial to today‚Äôs farms from the comfort of home. The conference allows attendees to dig deeper […] The post Crop Management Conference Equips Agriculturalists for Growing Season appeared first on
items.summary:
The conference costs $50 to attend, and participants must register by April 15 to access the content through a Learn @ Illinois Extension account. 

The conference aims to provide crop producers, agriculture consultants, industry professionals, and students with the latest research and information to support their farming operations. Key topics include agriculture safety, climate, digital agriculture, weed and disease control, pest management, soils, sustainability, and conservation.

Certified Crop Advisers can earn 0.5 to 1.0 Continuing Education Units (CEUs) by viewing the online presentations and completing quizzes. The sessions are 25-50 minutes long.

The conference is designed to give attendees more time to plan and strategize for the upcoming growing season. Extension specialist Talon Becker says the online format provides easier access to University-led research to help support farmers' priorities, profitability, and future success.

For questions or accommodation requests, attendees can contact Megan Weber, Extension program coordinator, at [email protected] or 217-265-5321. Early requests are encouraged to allow time to meet access needs.

items.title: FSIS extends comment period on salmonella strategy
items.description: Stakeholders have until March 4 to submit comments on practical strategies to reduce Salmonella in poultry products.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety & Inspection Service (FSIS) has extended the public comment period on its proposed strategy to reduce Salmonella in poultry products. The new deadline for submitting comments is March 4, 2023, extended from the original January 19 deadline.

FSIS is seeking feedback on practical and effective measures to lower Salmonella contamination rates in chicken and turkey products. Key elements of the proposed strategy include setting new performance standards, enhancing testing and sampling, and improving coordination with state and industry partners.

The initiative aims to achieve a 25% reduction in Salmonella illnesses linked to poultry within 5 years. Currently, Salmonella causes an estimated 1.35 million infections, 26,500 hospitalizations, and 420 deaths in the U.S. each year. Poultry products are a major source, responsible for about 23% of these cases.

Stakeholders including farmers, processors, consumer groups, and public health experts are encouraged to submit comments on the strategy's feasibility and potential impact on their operations or communities. FSIS will use the feedback to finalize the new Salmonella action plan later in 2023.

items.title: Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization
items.description: The appointment follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. The post Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Nutrien has appointed Chris Reynolds as the new leader of its global sales organization. This follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. Reynolds has over 25 years of experience in agriculture and will be responsible for Nutrien's global sales and marketing strategies. Nutrien is a major global supplier of crop inputs, including fertilizers, seeds, and crop protection products, with operations in 14 countries.

items.title: Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control
items.description: Experts to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment. The post Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Weed Science Society of America (WSSA) is hosting a symposium to discuss the future of targeted and autonomous weed control. Key points:

- The symposium will explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment.
- Experts from industry, academia, and government agencies will present the latest advancements in robotics, computer vision, artificial intelligence, and other technologies relevant to weed management.
- Topics will include autonomous weed scouting, precision herbicide application, and integrating these technologies into farming operations.
- The goal is to identify barriers and solutions to widespread adoption of targeted and autonomous weed control systems.
- The symposium will be held on February 13-16, 2023 in Arlington, Virginia as part of the WSSA Annual Meeting.
- Participants will include researchers, engineers, growers, and representatives from agricultural technology companies.
- The findings and recommendations from the symposium aim to guide future research, development, and deployment of these advanced weed control technologies.

items.title: Strong consumer demand keeps driving beef prices
items.description: Ag economist expects 2025 data to show slight drop in retail beef supply as production efficiencies no longer fully offset lower cattle numbers.
items.summary: According to Ag economist Derrell Peel, consumer demand is expected to keep beef prices strong despite a slight drop in retail beef supply by 2025. Peel projects a 0.9% decline in per capita beef supply, as production efficiencies can no longer fully offset lower cattle numbers. The U.S. cattle herd fell 2% in 2022 to 89 million head, the lowest level since 2015. Retail beef prices reached a record high of $7.48 per pound in August 2022, up 10.3% year-over-year. Peel believes cattle producers may expand herds in 2023 if profitability remains strong. However, drought conditions in the Southern Plains and West could limit the ability to grow the herd in the short term. Peel expects consumer demand to remain robust, supported by strong employment, rising wages, and limited supply growth.

items.title: Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase
items.description: January Ag Economy Barometer plunges as farmers report worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns, according to Purdue University. The post Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Ag Economy Barometer, a monthly survey of farmer sentiment conducted by Purdue University, showed a sharp drop in farmer confidence in January 2026. The barometer index fell to 97, down 29 points from December 2025. This was the lowest level recorded since August 2023.

Key findings:
- 40% of farmers reported their farm's financial position worsened in the last 3 months, up from 26% in December 2025.
- 44% expect their farm's financial performance to worsen in the next 12 months, up from 30% in December.
- 63% reported increasing farm debt, up from 57% in December.
- 44% were concerned about export opportunities, up from 35% in December.

Experts attributed the declining sentiment to growing economic concerns, including rising interest rates, high input costs, and uncertainty around export markets. This could negatively impact farmer investment and spending decisions in the year ahead.

The survey was conducted from January 16-20, 2026 and included 400 U.S. agricultural producers.

items.title: Soybean sales got aggressive last fall
items.description: Trade truce with China spurred higher U.S. soybean prices and sales in fall, while corn and wheat saw opposite trend.
items.summary:
U.S. soybean sales and prices saw a significant increase in fall 2022 following a trade truce with China. Soybean exports from the U.S. rose by 34% in September and 71% in October compared to the same months in 2021. This surge in soybean demand led to a 30% increase in soybean prices in September and a 22% increase in October. 

In contrast, corn and wheat exports declined during this period, with corn exports dropping by 10% in September and 9% in October, while wheat exports fell by 22% in September and 8% in October compared to 2021.

The improved U.S.-China trade relations, which included China's increased purchases of American agricultural products, were the primary driver behind the strong soybean performance. Experts believe this trend is likely to continue as China works to fulfill its commitments under the Phase One trade deal.

For farmers, the higher soybean prices and sales have provided a welcome boost to their revenues. However, the declining corn and wheat exports could pose challenges for those producers. Industry analysts recommend that farmers closely monitor market conditions and adjust their planting and sales strategies accordingly.

items.title: Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest
items.description: Collaboration advances Syngenta‚Äôs sustainability goal to grow 85% of seed production using regenerative practices by 2030. The post Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Syngenta, a leading agricultural company, has expanded its collaboration with Ducks Unlimited, a conservation organization, to scale up the adoption of regenerative agriculture practices in seed production across the Midwest region of the United States.

The key points are:
- Syngenta has set a goal to grow 85% of its seed production using regenerative practices by 2030.
- This expanded collaboration with Ducks Unlimited aims to accelerate the adoption of these practices in the Midwest.
- Regenerative agriculture focuses on improving soil health, increasing biodiversity, and reducing the environmental impact of farming.
- The partnership will provide support, resources, and technical assistance to farmers in the Midwest to help them transition to regenerative agriculture in their seed production operations.
- This initiative is expected to have a positive impact on farmers by improving soil health, increasing yields, and reducing input costs, while also benefiting the environment through reduced greenhouse gas emissions and improved water quality.
- The collaboration builds on the successful pilot program that Syngenta and Ducks Unlimited have been running in the Midwest since 2020.

items.title: Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made
items.description: Sugar is a common part of Americans' nutritional intake. Here's how sugar is created, starting with how it's produced on farms. The post Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
About 60% of U.S. sugar comes from sugar beets, which are large root crops typically grown in colder climates like Minnesota, Idaho, and North Dakota. The remaining 40% comes from sugar cane, a tropical grass crop grown in Florida and Louisiana.

To make sugar, the plants are harvested and the sugar juice is extracted. For sugar beets, this involves washing, slicing, and soaking the roots in water. For sugar cane, the stalks are crushed, soaked, and squeezed. The extracted juice is then filtered, boiled to thicken it, and finally crystallized. 

The sugar crystals from sugar beets are then dried and packaged, ready for use. Sugar cane, on the other hand, first produces a raw sugar that still needs further refining. This raw sugar is transported to a refinery where it is melted, filtered, and recrystallized to remove remaining impurities.

The sugar production process also yields other useful byproducts. Molasses is produced from the centrifuge step, and is used in animal feed, baking, and pharmaceuticals. The plant residues like beet pulp and cane stalks are also utilized, often as animal feed or fuel.

Interestingly, sugar is naturally white, and does not require any artificial whitening or additives. It is a simple, natural product that has an indefinite shelf life. While sometimes vilified, sugar can be part of a balanced diet when consumed in moderation.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
Kellie and AJ Blair have been using a drainage water recycling system for over 3 years as part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship. The system captures water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, stores it in a pond, and then reuses it for supplemental irrigation during droughts.

Building the pond was a larger conservation project than the Blairs had done before, but they saw potential benefits like reduced nutrient runoff and increased yields. While recent rains have limited their need for irrigation, Iowa State data has shown yield increases from the system. Experts like Chris Hay of Hay Water Solutions estimate the system can provide 3-4 inches of supplemental water per year on 125 acres.

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually, and save $10-$20 per acre in operating costs. The practice can also improve water quality by reducing nutrient runoff. However, these systems have high upfront costs of $2-3 million.

The Blairs recommend that farmers interested in drainage water recycling seek local expertise to design and implement the system. They are now looking to add features like a fertilizer injection system to further optimize their recycling setup. Overall, the practice shows promise but requires significant investment that may need public-private funding partnerships to be feasible for more farmers.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
George Gough, director of stakeholder relations for Bayer, says the company is hopeful the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in the case of Monsanto Company v. Durnell. In this case, Bayer will argue that it was following established laws and standards by not having a cancer warning on glyphosate, as the label was approved by the Environmental Protection Agency.

Gough acknowledged that Bayer has already publicly spent more than $12 billion on lawsuits over glyphosate. However, the company has won more cases than it has lost, with a 15-11 record, including nine consecutive wins. Bayer cites the lack of convincing scientific evidence that glyphosate causes cancer as the reason for its success in court.

If Bayer wins the Supreme Court case, it could help quell the tide of lawsuits, as thousands of claims are still in the system. However, Gough said the company may eventually have to exit the glyphosate business, which would be "a bad day, not just for Bayer, but for the growers in the United States." This is because the only other manufacturer of the herbicide is in China.

The constant litigation over glyphosate also provides a template for trial lawyers to go after other pesticides, making crop protection companies less likely to invest in developing new chemistries. Luther Markwart, CEO and executive vice president of the American Sugarbeet Growers Association, said the association is working on an amicus brief in the case going to the Supreme Court, as the development of Roundup Ready sugarbeets was a significant advancement for weed control in sugarbeets.

items.title: Starter Flock Program helps students get involved in the Targhee sheep breed
items.description: In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota, received her starter flock through the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. Now her breeding program continues to grow.
items.summary: S. Targhee Sheep Association. The program awards recipients with a starter flock, with at least one of the ewes being donated by members of the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. This program helps young people get started in the livestock industry by providing them with Targhee sheep, which is a breed the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association aims to promote. Annabel has continued to grow her Targhee sheep flock since receiving the starter flock.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In 2024, the City Green farm in the US produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds. This is crucial as conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and food systems. The seeds have become a symbol of hope for many Palestinians.

City Green is part of a larger network of US farmers dedicated to conserving Palestinian agricultural biodiversity. These farmers grow and share traditional Palestinian seed varieties to support food sovereignty and cultural preservation for Palestinian communities.

The article does not provide any additional details about the individuals, organizations, or locations involved. It also does not mention any specific impacts, recommendations, or expert quotes.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key points:

- The USDA is establishing a new sterile fly dispersal polygon extending 50 miles into Texas along the U.S.-Mexico border to prevent the northward spread of New World screwworm.

- The dispersal facility at Moore Air Base is expected to be fully operational within 2-3 weeks after initial testing this week.

- The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association welcomes the progress on the dispersal facility and increased fly production in Mexico, but until these measures are fully established, keeping the U.S.-Mexico border closed to livestock imports is the responsible course of action.

- USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins will keep the border closed to protect the U.S. livestock and wildlife from the significant threat posed by a potential New World screwworm incursion, which could have devastating economic consequences.

- The cattle association trusts USDA to make reopening decisions based on science and preparedness, and stands ready to support efforts to safeguard animal health until progress is made on pushing the fly further south.

- The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association is a 148-year-old trade association with over 28,000 members contributing to beef production and natural resource stewardship in the Southwest.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The National Chicken Council estimates 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed around Super Bowl LX, which would be enough to circle the Earth's equator more than three times.

Wholesale chicken wing prices are $1.12 per pound this year, up from 99 cents per pound at the start of 2026 but well below the $1.99 per pound price last year, $2.65 per pound in 2024, and $3.80 per pound in 2022. 

Around 17.5 billion wings are expected to be produced this year, meaning 8.5% of U.S. chicken wing production will be consumed during the Super Bowl. The article notes that chicken wings have become a cultural phenomenon, evolving from an "afterthought cut of meat" to one of the most sought-after items during sporting events.

The article cites comments from Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service economist David Anderson, who explains that the popularity of chicken wings for Super Bowl snacking has "melded pop culture, food and sports" in a way that has elevated them. Anderson plans to make wings for the big game himself this year.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle herd started 2026 with 86.2 million head, slightly lower than the previous year. This continues the industry's multi-year contraction.

Key numbers:
- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (as of Jan. 1, 2026)
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year) 
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from the prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

The report signals a slow start to herd rebuilding, as beef replacement heifers increased only modestly to 4.71 million head. With fewer beef cows and a smaller calf crop, near-term feeder supplies remain constrained, which is a tailwind for cattle prices.

For producers, the tight supplies mean strong calf and bred female prices, but rebuilding the herd will take time. Stocker and feedlot operators face elevated competition for feeder cattle. Expansion is likely to be slow and uneven, shaped more by forage conditions, replacement economics, and producer risk appetite than headline prices.

The data was collected by the USDA's National Agricultural Statistics Service through surveys of around 35,000 operators across the country in early January 2026.

items.title: Ridder Hereford Ranch Annual Bull & Heifer Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Jan. 29, 2026 Location: at the ranch – Callaway, NE Auctioneer: Lander Nicodemus Averages: 17 Yearling Hereford Bulls averaged $12,0599 Fall Hereford Bulls averaged $10,16761 2-year-old Hereford Bulls...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Ridder Hereford Ranch held its annual bull and heifer sale on January 29, 2026 at their ranch near Callaway, Nebraska.

- The sale featured 17 yearling Hereford bulls that averaged $12,059, 61 fall Hereford bulls that averaged $10,167, and 43 2-year-old Hereford bulls that averaged $8,885. 

- 61 open yearling Hereford heifers averaged $3,610.

- Top-selling bulls included:
    - Lot 36M - $20,500 (3/10/24 son of CL 1 Domino 1117J)
    - Lot 52M - $20,000 (3/14/24 son of CL 1 Domino 1117J) 
    - Lot 38N - $18,500 (3/15/25 son of CL 1 Domino 2126K)
    - Lot 35N - $17,000 (3/14/25 son of CL 1 Domino 0140H)
    - Lot 126M - $13,500 (10/16/24 son of CL 1 Domino 2126K)
    - Lot 124M - $12,500 (10/4/24 son of BCC L1 Advanced 9102G)

- Top-selling heifers included R Starlette 504, 561 and ER578 which all sold for $5,000 each.

- The sale was held both in-person and via LiveAg, with a large crowd attending in person.

- The Ridder family has a 119-year tradition of raising purebred Hereford cattle in the Sandhills of Nebraska.
